citation.fr:
[{"type": "dataset", "id": "ca.cioos_1755dc37-8d33-4158-8041-c22536fd5771", "author": [{"literal": "Hakai Institute"}], "issued": [{"date-parts": ["2022", "01", "13"]}], "abstract": "Cet ensemble de données comprend les concentrations de chlorophylle et de phaeopigment de l'Institut Hakai recueillies de 2015 à aujourd'hui dans les stations de l'île Calvert, du détroit de Johnstone et des régions étudiées de l'île Quadra. Des échantillons pour ces données ont été recueillis sur le terrain à l'aide de bouteilles Niskin. L'échantillon d'eau (250 ml) a été filtré à travers : 1) un seul filtre en fibre de verre (GF/F, taille nominale des pores 0,7 um) pour comprendre une mesure globale des concentrations de phytoplancton chlorophylle et de phaeopigment et 2) une pile de filtres (filtres en polycarbonate GF/F, 3 um et 20 um) pour estimer la chlorophylle et le phéopigment les concentrations de pico, de nano et de micro-phytoplancton, respectivement. Les filtres ont été extraits pendant 24 heures dans 10 ml d'acétone à 90 % et analysés sur des fluoromètres de laboratoire Turner Designs Trilogy à l'aide du module d'acidification et selon la méthode de Holm Hansen et al. (1965). 

Les données ont été contrôlées par une inspection manuelle, qui comprenait une comparaison des concentrations en vrac avec la somme des concentrations de filtres fractionnés par taille. Le cas échéant, d'autres comparaisons ont été effectuées avec d'autres mesures des concentrations de chlorophylle, y compris la fluorescence de la chlorophylle CTD in situ et les données de chromatographie liquide à haute performance (HPLC).

Les données ont été recueillies par les programmes océanographiques et côtiers de l'Institut Hakai.", "edition-date": "", "publisher": "Hakai Institute", "title": "Échantillons de concentrations de chlorophylle et de phéopigment en vrac et en fractionnement de taille de l'Institut Hakai prélevées à l'aide de bouteilles Niskin,  provisoire", "version": "1.0.0", "DOI": "10.21966/90h6-b497", "language": "fr", "URL": "https://catalogue.hakai.org/dataset/ca-cioos_1755dc37-8d33-4158-8041-c22536fd5771?local=fr"}]
citation.en:
[{"type": "dataset", "id": "ca.cioos_1755dc37-8d33-4158-8041-c22536fd5771", "author": [{"literal": "Hakai Institute"}], "issued": [{"date-parts": ["2022", "01", "13"]}], "abstract": "This dataset is comprised of Hakai Institute chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations collected from 2014 to present at stations within the Calvert Island, Johnstone Strait, and the Quadra Island study regions. Samples for these data were collected in the field using Niskin bottles. Sample water (250 ml) was filtered through: 1) a single glass fiber filter (GF/F, nominal pore size 0.7 um) to comprise a bulk measure of phytoplankton chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations and 2) a stack of filters (GF/F, 3 um, and 20 um polycarbonate filters) to estimate chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations from pico, nano, and micro-phytoplankton, respectively. Filters were extracted for 24 hours in 10 ml of 90% acetone and analyzed on Turner Designs Trilogy laboratory fluorometers using the acidification module and following the method of Holm Hansen et al. (1965). 

Data have been quality controlled by manual inspection which included a comparison of bulk concentrations against the sum of the size-fractionated filter concentrations. Where available, further comparisons were done with other measures of chlorophyll concentrations including in situ CTD chlorophyll fluorescence and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) data.

Data were collected by the Hakai Institute Oceanography and Nearshore programs.", "edition-date": "", "publisher": "Hakai Institute", "title": "Hakai Bulk and Size-Fractionated Chlorophyll and Phaeopigment Concentrations Collected by Niskin Bottle, Provisional", "version": "1.0.0", "DOI": "10.21966/90h6-b497", "language": "en", "URL": "https://catalogue.hakai.org/dataset/ca-cioos_1755dc37-8d33-4158-8041-c22536fd5771?local=en"}]

      <mri:abstract xsi:type="lan:PT_FreeText_PropertyType">
        <gco:CharacterString>This dataset is comprised of Hakai Institute chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations collected from 2014 to present at stations within the Calvert Island, Johnstone Strait, and the Quadra Island study regions. Samples for these data were collected in the field using Niskin bottles. Sample water (250 ml) was filtered through: 1) a single glass fiber filter (GF/F, nominal pore size 0.7 um) to comprise a bulk measure of phytoplankton chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations and 2) a stack of filters (GF/F, 3 um, and 20 um polycarbonate filters) to estimate chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations from pico, nano, and micro-phytoplankton, respectively. Filters were extracted for 24 hours in 10 ml of 90% acetone and analyzed on Turner Designs Trilogy laboratory fluorometers using the acidification module and following the method of Holm Hansen et al. (1965). 

Data have been quality controlled by manual inspection which included a comparison of bulk concentrations against the sum of the size-fractionated filter concentrations. Where available, further comparisons were done with other measures of chlorophyll concentrations including in situ CTD chlorophyll fluorescence and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) data.

Data were collected by the Hakai Institute Oceanography and Nearshore programs.</gco:CharacterString>
        <lan:PT_FreeText>
          <lan:textGroup xlink:href="https://cioos.ca/translation_method" xlink:role="translation" xlink:title="text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit  l'aide du service de traduction Amazon">
            <lan:LocalisedCharacterString locale="#fr">Cet ensemble de donnes comprend les concentrations de chlorophylle et de phaeopigment de l'Institut Hakai recueillies de 2015  aujourd'hui dans les stations de l'le Calvert, du dtroit de Johnstone et des rgions tudies de l'le Quadra. Des chantillons pour ces donnes ont t recueillis sur le terrain  l'aide de bouteilles Niskin. L'chantillon d'eau (250 ml) a t filtr  travers: 1) un seul filtre en fibre de verre (GF/F, taille nominale des pores 0,7 um) pour comprendre une mesure globale des concentrations de phytoplancton chlorophylle et de phaeopigment et 2) une pile de filtres (filtres en polycarbonate GF/F, 3 um et 20 um) pour estimer la chlorophylle et le phopigment les concentrations de pico, de nano et de micro-phytoplancton, respectivement. Les filtres ont t extraits pendant 24 heures dans 10 ml d'actone  90% et analyss sur des fluoromtres de laboratoire Turner Designs Trilogy  l'aide du module d'acidification et selon la mthode de Holm Hansen et al. (1965). 

Les donnes ont t contrles par une inspection manuelle, qui comprenait une comparaison des concentrations en vrac avec la somme des concentrations de filtres fractionns par taille. Le cas chant, d'autres comparaisons ont t effectues avec d'autres mesures des concentrations de chlorophylle, y compris la fluorescence de la chlorophylle CTD in situ et les donnes de chromatographie liquide  haute performance (HPLC).

Les donnes ont t recueillies par les programmes ocanographiques et ctiers de l'Institut Hakai.</lan:LocalisedCharacterString>
          </lan:textGroup>
        </lan:PT_FreeText>
      </mri:abstract>

          <mco:useLimitation xsi:type="lan:PT_FreeText_PropertyType">
            <gco:CharacterString>The utilized acidification method is sensitive to interference by high concentrations of chlorophyll c and b. High chlorophyll c concentrations can cause a slight overestimation of chlorophyll a and an underestimation of phaeopigments: negative phaeopigment concentrations can occur during bloom events with high chlorophyll c and healthy phytoplankton. High chlorophyll b concentrations can result in underestimations of chlorophyll a and overestimations of phaeopigments. When chlorophyll b is high relative to chlorophyll a, chlorophyll a can be underestimated by as much as 2.5 fold. For more details see Welschmeyer et al. (1994). These two types of interference likely had an influence on the published chlorophyll and phaeopigment dataset. Notably, comparison with HPLC has shown that stations in the Quadra Island region often experience conditions where chlorophyll b is present in high concentrations and is high relative to chlorophyll a.

The acidification method used to analyze the Hakai Institute dataset has been shown to highly overestimate phaeopigment concentrations based on comparison to concentrations determined by HPLC (Trees et al., 2003). Care should be used when interpreting the published phaeopigment concentrations. 

Prior to 2021, samples that exceeded the manufacturer specified instrument sensitivity range were not diluted to bring their concentrations within the specified range. Samples run above the instrument sensitivity range may have underestimated chlorophyll concentrations due to the blockage of light passing through the sample and a corresponding reduction of fluorescence output (see Turner Trilogy user manual for complete description). Comparison with matching HPLC derived chlorophyll a suggests that the affected samples may be useable, but further analysis is required. This provisional dataset includes these data.

Prior to 2018, annual calibrations of the Hakai Institute Turner Trilogy benchtop fluorometers showed variability in the calibration slopes and acid ratios that were applied to the data. The inconsistent nature of this variability suggests error due to analytical methods rather than instrument drift. As a result, the chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations of the data where these calibrations were applied may have error as high as +/- 12 % from this source alone. These data have been included in this provisional dataset. 

Prior to 2018, QA/QC analysis suggests potential influence by acid contamination on the chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations (i.e. very low chlorophyll a and high phaeopigment concentrations where the CTD fluorometer and HPLC showed high chlorophyll a). In 2018, methodological controls were put in place to limit acid contamination and the issue ceased. Care has been taken to flag the contaminated data, but data with less obvious contamination effects may not have been captured by QA/QC and may be present in this provisional dataset.

This provisional dataset includes all data flagged as "suspicious" (show suspicious trends, but may not be incorrect), but excludes data flagged as "discard" (clearly erroneous).</gco:CharacterString>

Lorsque la chlorophylle b est leve par rapport  la chlorophylle a, la chlorophylle a peut tre sous-estime jusqu' 2,5 fois. Pour plus de dtails, voir Welschmeyer et coll. (1994). Ces deux types d'interfrences ont probablement eu une influence sur le jeu de donnes publi sur la chlorophylle et le phopigment. Notamment, la comparaison avec le HPLC a montr que les stations de la rgion de l'le Quadra connaissent souvent des conditions o la chlorophylle b est prsente  des concentrations leves et est leve par rapport  la chlorophylle a.

Il a t dmontr que la mthode d'acidification utilise pour analyser le jeu de donnes de l'Institut Hakai surestime fortement les concentrations de phaeopigment sur la base de la comparaison avec les concentrations dtermines par HPLC (Trees et al., 2003). Par consquent, les concentrations de chlorophylle et de phopigment des donnes o ces talonnages ont t appliqus peuvent prsenter des erreurs allant jusqu' +/- 12% par rapport  cette seule source. Ces donnes ont t incluses dans cet ensemble de donnes provisoire.

name: ca-cioos_1755dc37-8d33-4158-8041-c22536fd57711
notes:
This dataset is comprised of Hakai Institute chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations collected from 2014 to present at stations within the Calvert Island, Johnstone Strait, and the Quadra Island study regions. Samples for these data were collected in the field using Niskin bottles. Sample water (250 ml) was filtered through: 1) a single glass fiber filter (GF/F, nominal pore size 0.7 um) to comprise a bulk measure of phytoplankton chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations and 2) a stack of filters (GF/F, 3 um, and 20 um polycarbonate filters) to estimate chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations from pico, nano, and micro-phytoplankton, respectively. Filters were extracted for 24 hours in 10 ml of 90% acetone and analyzed on Turner Designs Trilogy laboratory fluorometers using the acidification module and following the method of Holm Hansen et al. (1965). 

Data have been quality controlled by manual inspection which included a comparison of bulk concentrations against the sum of the size-fractionated filter concentrations. Where available, further comparisons were done with other measures of chlorophyll concentrations including in situ CTD chlorophyll fluorescence and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) data.

Data were collected by the Hakai Institute Oceanography and Nearshore programs.

Filters were extracted for 24 hours in 10 ml of 90% acetone and analyzed on Turner Designs Trilogy laboratory fluorometers using the acidification module and following the method of Holm Hansen et al. (1965). 

Data have been quality controlled by manual inspection which included a comparison of bulk concentrations against the sum of the size-fractionated filter concentrations. notes_translated.fr:
Cet ensemble de donnes comprend les concentrations de chlorophylle et de phaeopigment de l'Institut Hakai recueillies de 2015  aujourd'hui dans les stations de l'le Calvert, du dtroit de Johnstone et des rgions tudies de l'le Quadra. Des chantillons pour ces donnes ont t recueillis sur le terrain  l'aide de bouteilles Niskin. L'chantillon d'eau (250 ml) a t filtr  travers: 1) un seul filtre en fibre de verre (GF/F, taille nominale des pores 0,7 um) pour comprendre une mesure globale des concentrations de phytoplancton chlorophylle et de phaeopigment et 2) une pile de filtres (filtres en polycarbonate GF/F, 3 um et 20 um) pour estimer la chlorophylle et le phopigment les concentrations de pico, de nano et de micro-phytoplancton, respectivement. Les filtres ont t extraits pendant 24 heures dans 10 ml d'actone  90% et analyss sur des fluoromtres de laboratoire Turner Designs Trilogy  l'aide du module d'acidification et selon la mthode de Holm Hansen et al. (1965). 

Les donnes ont t contrles par une inspection manuelle, qui comprenait une comparaison des concentrations en vrac avec la somme des concentrations de filtres fractionns par taille. Le cas chant, d'autres comparaisons ont t effectues avec d'autres mesures des concentrations de chlorophylle, y compris la fluorescence de la chlorophylle CTD in situ et les donnes de chromatographie liquide  haute performance (HPLC).

Les donnes ont t recueillies par les programmes ocanographiques et ctiers de l'Institut Hakai.

The inconsistent nature of this variability suggests error due to analytical methods rather than instrument drift. As a result, the chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations of the data where these calibrations were applied may have error as high as +/- 12 % from this source alone. These data have been included in this provisional dataset. 

Prior to 2018, QA/QC analysis suggests potential influence by acid contamination on the chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations (i.e. very low chlorophyll a and high phaeopigment concentrations where the CTD fluorometer and HPLC showed high chlorophyll a). In 2018, methodological controls were put in place to limit acid contamination and the issue ceased. Care has been taken to flag the contaminated data, but data with less obvious contamination effects may not have been captured by QA/QC and may be present in this provisional dataset.

This provisional dataset includes all data flagged as "suspicious" (show suspicious trends, but may not be incorrect), but excludes data flagged as "discard" (clearly erroneous).

The utilized acidification method is sensitive to interference by high concentrations of chlorophyll c and b. High chlorophyll c concentrations can cause a slight overestimation of chlorophyll a and an underestimation of phaeopigments: negative phaeopigment concentrations can occur during bloom events with high chlorophyll c and healthy phytoplankton. High chlorophyll b concentrations can result in underestimations of chlorophyll a and overestimations of phaeopigments. When chlorophyll b is high relative to chlorophyll a, chlorophyll a can be underestimated by as much as 2.5 fold. For more details see Welschmeyer et al. (1994). These two types of interference likely had an influence on the published chlorophyll and phaeopigment dataset. Notably, comparison with HPLC has shown that stations in the Quadra Island region often experience conditions where chlorophyll b is present in high concentrations and is high relative to chlorophyll a.

The acidification method used to analyze the Hakai Institute dataset has been shown to highly overestimate phaeopigment concentrations based on comparison to concentrations determined by HPLC (Trees et al., 2003). Care should be used when interpreting the published phaeopigment concentrations. 

Prior to 2021, samples that exceeded the manufacturer specified instrument sensitivity range were not diluted to bring their concentrations within the specified range. Samples run above the instrument sensitivity range may have underestimated chlorophyll concentrations due to the blockage of light passing through the sample and a corresponding reduction of fluorescence output (see Turner Trilogy user manual for complete description). Comparison with matching HPLC derived chlorophyll a suggests that the affected samples may be useable, but further analysis is required. This provisional dataset includes these data.

Prior to 2018, annual calibrations of the Hakai Institute Turner Trilogy benchtop fluorometers showed variability in the calibration slopes and acid ratios that were applied to the data. The inconsistent nature of this variability suggests error due to analytical methods rather than instrument drift. As a result, the chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations of the data where these calibrations were applied may have error as high as +/- 12 % from this source alone. These data have been included in this provisional dataset. 

Prior to 2018, QA/QC analysis suggests potential influence by acid contamination on the chlorophyll and phaeopigment concentrations (i.e. very low chlorophyll a and high phaeopigment concentrations where the CTD fluorometer and HPLC showed high chlorophyll a). In 2018, methodological controls were put in place to limit acid contamination and the issue ceased. Care has been taken to flag the contaminated data, but data with less obvious contamination effects may not have been captured by QA/QC and may be present in this provisional dataset.

This provisional dataset includes all data flagged as "suspicious" (show suspicious trends, but may not be incorrect), but excludes data flagged as "discard" (clearly erroneous).
